title: Safe Arrival and Dismissal Policy and Procedures
content:
Safe Arrival and Dismissal Policy and Procedures
Purpose
This policy and the procedures within help support the safe arrival and dismissal of children receiving care at Central Montessori School. This policy will provide staff, students and volunteers with a clear understanding of their roles and responsibilities for ensuring the safe arrival and dismissal of children receiving care, including what steps are to be taken when a child does not arrive at the childcare centre as expected, as well as steps to follow to ensure the safe dismissal of children. This policy is intended to fulfill the obligations set out under Ontario Regulation 137/15 for policies and procedures regarding the safe arrival and dismissal of children in care.

Policy
General
Central Montessori School will ensure that any child receiving child care is only released to the child's parent/guardian, or an individual that the parent/guardian has provided written authorization allowing the child care centre to release the child. Central Montessori School will only dismiss children into the care of their parent/guardian or another authorized individual. The centre will not release any children from care without supervision. When a child does not arrive in care as expected or is not picked up as expected, staff must follow the safe arrival and dismissal procedures set out below.

Policy Statements
Procedure:
Children will only be released to adults who are permitted by the parents and listed on the child's file or if written consent has been provided.

Accepting a child into care
When accepting a child into care at the time of drop-off, program staff in the room must:
Greet the parent/guardian and child.
Where the parent/guardian indicates that someone other than the child's parent/guardians will be picking up, the staff must confirm that the person is listed on the student pick-up list on the child's file or, where the individual is not listed, ask the parent/guardian to provide authorization for pick-up in writing (e.g., note or email).
Document the change in the pick-up procedure in the daily written record.
Sign the child in on the classroom attendance record.

Where a child has not arrived in care as expected
Where a child does not arrive at the Central Montessori School, and the parent/guardian has not communicated a change in drop-off (e.g., left a voice message or advised the closing staff at pick-up), the staff in the classroom must:
Inform the supervisor/designee. The staff must commence contacting the child's parent/guardian no later than 10:00 am, and leave a message if there is no response. If no response is received after/within 4 hours, the staff will report to the supervisor/designee.
The supervisor/designee will contact the emergency person listed on file.
Once the child's absence has been confirmed, program staff shall document the child's absence on the attendance record and any additional information about the child's absence in the daily written record.

Releasing a child from care
The staff who is supervising the child at the time of pick-up shall only release the child to the child's parent/guardian or an individual that the parent/guardian has provided written authorization for. Where the staff does not know the individual picking up the child (i.e., parent/guardian or authorized individual), they must:
Confirm with another staff member that the individual is the child's parent/guardian/authorized pick-up.
Where the above is not possible, ask the parent/guardian/authorized individual for photo identification and confirm the individual's identity against the information on the child's file or written authorization. A copy of the identification will be kept in the child's file.

Where a child has not been picked up as expected (before the centre closes)
Where a parent/guardian has communicated a specific time or time frame for pick-up and the child has not been picked up at that time, the staff/supervisor/designee will call the parent/guardian to advise that the child is still in care and has not been picked up.
Where staff is unable to reach the parent/guardian, staff must leave a message. If staff does not hear from the parent/guardian after 15 minutes, the emergency contact listed on the child's file will be contacted. Where an authorized individual is responsible for pick-up and their contact information is available, staff shall contact them to confirm pick-up or leave a voicemail.
If no response is received from the parent/guardian or authorized individual, staff shall wait until program close (6 pm) and then follow procedures under "where a child has not been picked up and the program is closed".

Where a child has not been picked up and the centre is closed
Where a parent/guardian or authorized individual was scheduled to pick up the child and has not arrived by 6 pm, staff shall ensure that the child is provided a snack and activity. One staff will stay with the child while another attempts to contact the parent/guardian to advise they are still in care.
If the staff is unable to reach the parent/guardian, they will proceed to call the authorized individual. If unsuccessful, they will then call the emergency contact listed in the child's file.
Where staff is unable to reach any parent/guardian or authorized individual (including emergency contacts) by 7 pm, staff shall contact the local Children's Aid Society (CAS) at 416-924-4646 and follow CAS direction.

Dismissing a child from care without supervision procedure
Staff will only release children to the parent/guardian or other authorized adult. Under no circumstances will children be released to walk home alone.

The policy will be reviewed by the staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment at CMS, and annually thereafter or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated by the person who participated and conducted the review. This record will be maintained for a minimum of 3 years.

title: Sleep Supervision Policy and Procedures (Toddler & Preschool)
content:
The Sleep Supervision Policy and Procedures (Toddler & Preschool)
The CMS Sleep Supervision Policy’s intent is to reduce the risk of harm or injury when children are sleeping. Parents/Guardians of children who regularly sleep at the center will be initially consulted with respect to their child’s sleeping arrangements, sleeping preferences, precautions and required accommodations at the time of enrollment and at any time changes might be required, such as during transitions between programs/room, or when changes are requested by parents. Special sleeping instruction will be recorded on a child’s application annually or as changes are required thereafter. Staff will be informed of a child’s sleeping arrangements by the office upon initial registration, annually thereafter, or when changes are requested or made. Significant changes in a child’s sleeping patterns or behaviours will be immediately communicated with parents as they arise verbally or through the daily communicable book.

General Procedures:
Children are assigned to individual cots labelled with the child’s name and class number/name to identify which children are present in the area or room.

Cots comply with the standards in the regulations made under the Canada Consumer Product Safety Act.

Parents will be consulted at the time of enrollment with respect to a child’s sleeping arrangements.

There must be sufficient light in the sleeping area or room to conduct direct visual checks of children through the use of lamps or leaving blinds open (as required).

Staff must perform a direct visual check of all sleeping children every 30 minutes by being physically present beside the child while the child is sleeping and looking for indicators of distress or unusual behaviours such as: changes in the colour of the skin, breathing patterns, signs of overheating, etc. Staff will document the direct visual checks being conducted on every child’s sleep tracking sheet.

The observance of any significant changes in a child’s sleeping patterns or behaviours during sleep will be tracked and communicated to parents verbally. This might result in adjustments to the manner in which the child is supervised during sleep and details regarding the performance of direct visual checks and how frequently direct visual checks will be performed.

System to identify the use of Sleep Room:

Staff are required to record sleeping children’s name in their daily log book and ensure that the time of their return to the classroom is logged to ensure children are accounted for at all times, whether in the sleep room or in the classroom.

This policy will be reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment at CMS, and annually thereafter, or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated by the person who participated and conducted the review and will be kept for a minimum of 3 years.

title: Serious Occurrence Policy
content:
Serious occurrences must be reported to the Ministry as defined under the Child Care and Early Years Act. These include: the death of a child, abuse or alleged abuse, life-threatening injury or illness, a missing or temporarily unsupervised child, and any unplanned disruption to operations that creates a risk to health or safety. Staff must respond immediately depending on the situation: call 911 for death, life-threatening injury, illness, fire, gas leak, carbon monoxide, or lockdown; call CAS for allegations of abuse or neglect; contact Toronto Public Health during outbreaks; contact City services for flood (311). Serious Occurrences must be reported through CCLS within 24 hours, and the Program Advisor must also be notified within 24 hours. A Serious Occurrence Notification Form must be posted for a minimum of 10 business days, protecting all personal information (no names, initials, ages, or room identifiers). An internal inquiry must begin immediately, collecting details including description, allegation, date/time, reason, people involved, actions taken, and current status. If abuse is suspected, CAS must be contacted by the person with reasonable grounds. Supervisors conduct an annual analysis of all serious occurrences and maintain records for 3 years. Employers must report RECE incidents involving misconduct, suspension, termination, or resignation under investigation to the College of ECE within 30 days.

DEFINITION: Serious occurrences to be reported by CMS to the ministry are defined as follows in the Child Care and Early Years Act: The death of a child who received child care at the child care centre, whether it occurs on or off premises; Abuse, neglect or an allegation of abuse or neglect of a child while receiving child care at the centre; A life-threatening injury to or a life-threatening illness of a child who receives child care at the centre; An incident where a child who is receiving child care at the centre goes missing or is temporarily unsupervised; or An unplanned disruption of the normal operations of a child care centre that poses a risk to the health, safety or well-being or children receiving child care at the centre. Note: Within the parameters of the preceding definitions, Central Montessori School is responsible for determining whether an incident is deemed to be a serious occurrence as defined by these procedures, and whether it should be reported to the ministry.

RESPONDING TO A SERIOUS OCCURRENCE: Death of a child: 911. Allegation of Abuse and/or Neglect: Children's Aid Society (CAS) 416-924-4646. Ministry Program Advisor. Life-threatening Injury or Illness: Injury: 911. Illness: 911 & Toronto Public Health. Missing or Unsupervised Child: 911 Police Department - CAS - Ministry Program Advisor. Unplanned Disruption of Normal Operations: Fire – 911 Fire Department. Flood – 311 City of Toronto. Gas Leak – 911 Direct Energy 1-866-763-5427. Detection of Carbon Monoxide – 911 City of Toronto 311. Outbreak – Toronto Public Health 416-338-7600. Lockdown – 911. Other Emergency Relocation or Temporary Closure – 911 Ministry Program Advisor (through CCLS) Toronto Public Health 416-338-7600.

REPORTING PROCEDURES: A Serious Occurrence must be reported online using the Child Care Licensing Information System (CCLS) within 24 hours. Any other occurrence to be deemed serious must be reported within 24 hours. As of Oct. 1st, 2016, it is no longer required to report serious occurrences to the City of Toronto. Reports will automatically be forwarded to Children Services. The report must be provided to the program advisor within 24 hours via telephone or email.

SERIOUS OCCURRENCE NOTIFICATION FORM: Following submission of the Serious Occurrences on CCLS, the operator will print out a Serious Occurrence Notification Form to communicate information to parents. The form will be posted near the Child Care Licence and Licensing Summary Chart for a minimum of 10 business days. Updates restart the 10-day period. Personal information must not be included (names, initials, ages, birth dates, room identifiers).

ACTIONS TO BE TAKEN: The child shall receive immediate medical attention if needed. Address any continuing risks. Notify the coroner immediately in all cases involving death. Witnesses must report information to the designated person. The supervisor must begin an inquiry immediately. All persons with knowledge of the occurrence must remain available until interviewed. Inquiry details should include: description, allegations, date/time, reason, people involved, actions taken, status, coroner info, further recommendations (police, CAS, parents, others). If there is reasonable suspicion of abuse, CAS must be contacted by the person who suspects it. If alleged abuse occurred at CMS, CAS and the Program Advisor must be notified. If the supervisor is absent, the administrator reports; if both are absent, the Head of School reports.

ANNUAL ANALYSIS: Completed by Supervisor. Used to identify issues, trends, and actions. Records kept for 3 years. Policy reviewed annually and stored securely for 3 years.

EMPLOYER’S MANDATORY REPORTING: Employers must report to the College of Early Childhood Educators if an RECE is terminated, suspended, restricted, or resigns under investigation. Reports of misconduct must be submitted within 30 days, including the Serious Occurrence report.

title: Sleep Supervision Policy and Procedures (Infants)
content:
The Sleep Supervision Policy and Procedures (Infants)
The purpose of this policy and procedures is to reduce the risk of harm and injury, including death, when infants are sleeping. CMS will ensure that children younger than 12 months of age are placed for sleep in a manner consistent with the recommendation as set out in the Public Health’s “Joint Statement on Safe Sleep: Preventing Sudden Infant Deaths in Canada.”

Note: The current recommendation set out in the most current version of the Joint Statement on Safe Sleep: Preventing Sudden Infant Deaths in Canada is that children up to their first birthday be placed on their backs for sleep. This requirement can only be waived if a medical doctor/physician recommends otherwise in writing. Once infants are able to roll from their backs to their stomachs or sides, it is not necessary to reposition them onto their backs.

Procedure:
Children are assigned to individual cribs labelled with their name and a picture card placed above their crib to immediately identify which children are present in the area or room.

Cribs comply with the standards in the regulations made under the Canada Consumer Product Safety Act. A document will be completed for each crib in the infant room and filed in a secure location with the make, model number and the year it was produced.

Annual checks will be conducted and documented to confirm that the cribs meet the standards as set out in the Public Health Agency of Canada’s Joint Statement on Safe Sleep. This document will be filed and maintained at CMS for three years.

Parents are consulted with respect to a child’s sleeping arrangement verbally at the time of enrollment, and at any time changes might be required, such as during transitions between programs/room, or when changes are requested by parents. Parents will also be advised that children 12 months and younger will be placed on their backs for sleep in accordance with the Joint Statement on Safe Sleep. CMS shall adhere to these recommendations unless a child’s physician recommends otherwise in writing regarding alternate sleep positions. This information is transferred to the “sleep card” placed over the child’s crib and reviewed by staff in the infant room.

Parents will be consulted before an infant is transitioned to the toddler room and will receive a consent letter to approve the transition of their child from an infant crib to a cot for nap time. This letter will be signed and dated by the parents and staff and placed in the child’s file.

Infants are safest when placed to sleep in fitted one-piece sleepwear comfortable at room temperature to reduce the risk of overheating and minimize the use of blankets. If a blanket is used, it must be breathable. No extra items such as pillows, duvets, or bumper pads may be placed in the crib.

There must be sufficient light in the sleeping area or room to conduct direct visual checks of children through the use of lamps or leaving blinds open.

Staff must perform a direct visual check of all sleeping children every 15 minutes by being physically present beside the child and looking for indicators of distress or unusual behaviours such as changes in skin colour, breathing patterns, or signs of overheating. Staff will document direct visual checks on each child’s sleep tracking sheet.

The observance of any significant changes in a child’s sleeping patterns or behaviours during sleep will be tracked and communicated to parents either verbally or through daily reports. This may result in adjustments to how the child is supervised during sleep and how frequently direct visual checks are performed.

Strollers, swings, bouncers and car seats are not intended for infant sleep. An infant’s head can fall forward when sleeping in a seated position and cause airway constriction. Once an infant falls asleep, the child should be moved as soon as possible or once at the destination to sleep in a crib.

System to identify the use of Sleep Room:
Staff are required to place the name tag of children sleeping in the sleep room on the door or wall outside the room.
When there are more than 3 infants in the sleep room, one staff member must be physically present inside the sleep room.

Electronic Monitoring Devices:
Electronic sleep monitoring devices are not used as a replacement for direct visual checks. Staff must still conduct checks according to regulations. Devices must be checked daily to ensure they are functioning properly. The time, date and condition of the device will be documented on the device tracking sheet.
If a device is not working, staff shall inform the supervisor for repair or removal.

This policy will be reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment at CMS, and annually thereafter, or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated by the person who participated and will be maintained for a minimum of 3 years in a secure location at CMS.

title: Supervision of Students & Volunteers Policy
content:
Supervision of Students & Volunteers Policy

Central Montessori School supports the education of future professionals through field placements, and volunteers as an additional support and value to our programs.

Students and volunteers are supervised and function under the direction of qualified CMS staff, and must never be left alone with children or replace a staff member.

Expectations of Students and Volunteers

Students and Volunteers:
- must be 18 years or older
- are never left alone with the children, are not included in staffing ratios, and will be supervised and mentored by a qualified CMS teaching staff member at all times
- are required to wear identification badges or tags
- are required to obtain a Vulnerable Sector Check
- must review and sign the Prohibited Practices Policy, and receive all CMS policies & procedures and existing Individual Support Plans before commencing placement
- must review and sign the Anaphylaxis Policy and emergency procedures with a CMS supervisor/principal or mentoring staff before commencement of placement
- must notify their Supervisor/Principal as soon as possible if they are to be absent. Sick individuals should not attend school. If showing signs of fever, vomiting, diarrhea, or communicable diseases (pink eye, chicken pox, etc.), they must stay home until no longer ill or cleared by a doctor
- are urged to use tact, diplomacy and politeness when dealing with management, parents and teachers. They must use “Mr.” “Mrs.” “Miss” when speaking with the Supervisor/Principal, other staff, and parents. Difficulties should be reported to the Supervisor/Principal immediately
- must never address parents on a first name basis unless specifically requested by the parent
- must refer parents to the classroom teacher if asked questions about the child or program
- shall not have lunch or make private arrangements with parents or children outside of school or during school hours unless approved by the Principal/Head of School
- shall not use confidential information, photographs, or video of any child or employee for any purpose unless written consent is received from the Head of School/Principal/Supervisor
- must never give any parent’s or employee’s phone number, address, or other personal information to anyone
- must not speak in a foreign language in front of children. Only English may be spoken unless language lessons (French, Spanish, etc.) are in progress. All children must be spoken to in English at all times unless otherwise approved
- must adhere to the appropriate dress code policy

Roles and Responsibilities of Students and Volunteers:
- General supervised participation and engagement with students during daily activities and planned program
- Assisting classroom teachers and engaging with students during arts & crafts, science, cooking, etc.
- Assisting classroom teachers with general classroom management
- Assisting with general classroom maintenance and cleaning
- Assisting with lunch routine (set-up, serving, and clean-up with children)

Supervision

The CMS supervisor/principal is responsible for supervising students and volunteers, and will assign daily supervision and responsibilities to a mentoring teacher.

Expectations of the mentoring teacher:
- must clearly explain what is expected of the student/volunteer during their placement
- must treat students/volunteers the same as paid staff, offering equal respect and opportunities for skill development
- must never leave children unattended with a student/volunteer
- must not include students/volunteers to uphold ratios
- must ensure students/volunteers remain in sight while working with children
- must be able and willing to offer necessary support for a successful placement
- must introduce students/volunteers to parents

This policy will be reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before beginning employment/placement at CMS, and annually thereafter or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated by participants and kept for a minimum of 3 years.

title: Waiting List Policy & Procedures
content:
Waiting List Policy & Procedures

Central Montessori Schools (CMS) does not charge or collect a fee for the placement of a child on a school waiting list for admission at any of our locations.

Priority shall be given to transfers from other CMS locations, siblings of existing students, and children of CMS employees.

In order to be placed on a waiting list, families must provide a completed admission form, signed on the day the child will be placed on the list. All information collected will be private and confidential, only to be used for admission purposes by school administrators. The information on the waiting list will be available in a manner that maintains the privacy of children listed on it, and information will be given to parents/guardians regarding the position of their child on the list upon request. Visible information on other children and their families will be physically concealed (using blank paper to cover the names of others on the list before and after the child in question), but the position of the child being inquired about will be disclosed to parents/guardians.

Upon availability of placement, admission from the waiting list is determined on a first-come, first-served basis according to the date on the application or the day the child was placed on the list.

Once placement can be secured, a non-refundable, one-time registration fee of $500 is payable to CMS.

This policy will be reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment at CMS, and annually thereafter, or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated by the person who participated and conducted the review and will be kept for a minimum of 3 years.

title: Staff Development & Training Policy
content:
Staff Development and Training Policy

POLICY STATEMENT:

Central Montessori School (CMS) is committed to providing high quality child care through ongoing professional staff training and development. We believe that the quality of the program depends on staff having knowledge of current theories in brain/child development and practices in the Montessori/Early Childhood Profession. Professional development is a joint responsibility of staff and administration. We also encourage staff to engage in their own professional development outside of work.

DEFINITIONS:

Professional Development and Training refers to all opportunities for advancement and learning that are planned for both in-house and outside the school. These may include workshops, conferences, webinars, events, observations, reading of articles, books and current studies, or meetings/programs reflecting changes within the Ministry of Education and Childcare Quality Assurance and Licensing, as well as topics relating to brain development, child physical/social/emotional development, cognition and pedagogy.

Orientation refers to job-specific policy review and training of new staff, students and volunteers.

IMPLEMENTATION AND GUIDELINES:

Every new staff member, student or volunteer working at CMS shall participate in an official Orientation to receive training, information and documents on up-to-date policies and procedures relating to CMS guidelines, Public Health, Fire Safety, and Ministry of Education/Childcare Quality Assurance and Licensing.

It is the responsibility of the authorized Supervisor or Principal to meet with classroom staff monthly to discuss and suggest areas that need improvement through further development/training of the program or staff members who may benefit from in-school training, self-directed reading, or observations in appropriate settings.

All CMS staff are eligible for mandatory and optional training and workshops offered by (or through) the school.

To maintain proper supervision and provide quality care for children, only one staff from each classroom shall participate in development and training at a time during program hours, unless approval has been granted by the Head of School.

All staff members are required to attend regular staff meetings in which:
- Resources, skills, ideas, professional experiences and expertise are shared.
- Current and new policies and procedures of CMS and the Ministry of Education/Childcare Quality Assurance and Licensing are reviewed.
- Staff decisions are made regarding upcoming school events and occasions.

FIRST AID AND CPR:

All staff who work at CMS must complete and maintain Standard First Aid with level C CPR (infant, child, and adult).

A mandatory refresher course is provided each school year. CMS will cover half of the cost of this course.

title: Program Statement Implementation Policy
content:
CMS Program Statement Implementation Policy

Our Program Statement Implementation Policy sets out the expectations for all staff, students and volunteers and guidance on how to implement the approaches specified in our Program Statement. All of our policies and procedures are reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment or placement at CMS, annually thereafter, and at any time a revision occurs.

Our Program Statement describes our aims for children and the approaches that we implement to meet these goals. In this document we will further cover the expectations of staff for each provision in ss.46 (3) (a-k) as set out under the Child Care and Early Years Act and Ontario regulation 137/15.

Promoting the health, safety, nutrition and well-being of children (s.46 (3) (a))
PROHIBITED PRACTICES
CMS prohibits all types of physical punishment and other harmful disciplinary actions for the protection of the emotional and physical well-being of children. The prohibited practices are as follows:
- corporal punishment of the child;
- physical restraint of the child, such as confining the child to a high chair, car seat, stroller or other device for the purposes of discipline or in lieu of supervision, unless the physical restraint is for the purpose of preventing a child from hurting himself, herself or someone else, and is used only as a last resort and only until the risk of injury is no longer imminent;
- locking the exits of the child care centre or home child care premises for the purpose of confining the child, or confining the child in an area or room without adult supervision, unless such confinement occurs during an emergency and is required as part of the licensee’s emergency management policies and procedures;
- use of harsh or degrading measures or threats or use of derogatory language directed at or used in the presence of a child that would humiliate, shame or frighten the child or undermine his or her self-respect, dignity or self-worth;
- depriving the child of basic needs including food, drink, shelter, sleep, toilet use, clothing or bedding; or
- inflicting any bodily harm on children including making children eat or drink against their will.

Suggested Procedures for Child Guidance & Preferred Practices
If a child is displaying negative or destructive behaviour, he/she shall be guided or redirected in ways that reinforce positive conduct. Staff shall point out acceptable behaviour rather than negative behaviour and allow the child to correct his/her own conduct whenever appropriate.
Continued disciplinary actions or issues must be reported to the Supervisor/Principal/Head of School. If required, an Individualized Support Plan may be required.

Involvement of Parents
Parents must be informed of changes in their child’s behaviour that cause concern.
The Supervisor/Principal/Head of School must be advised of any child whose actions endanger the safety of the environment, show persistent resistance to authority, or do not respond to guidance.
Actions may include:
- Hiring extra staff
- Using the services of a consultant
- Asking parents to withdraw the child

CONTRAVENTION OF PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION POLICY
All staff, students and volunteers must comply with the CMS Program Statement Implementation Policy and the Child Care and Early Years Act. Any contravention will result in discipline according to Contravention Levels I, II, and III.

DISCIPLINE IN THE CASE OF CONTRAVENTIONS I – REPORTING
- Each contravention must be reported immediately to the Supervisor/Principal/Head of School.
- The Supervisor must investigate within one working day.
- For each confirmed contravention, appropriate action must be taken.

DISCIPLINE IN THE CASE OF CONTRAVENTION II – INVESTIGATION
The Supervisor must meet with the staff member within 24 hours to:
- Identify the difficulty and reason
- Decide whether an offence occurred and classify it as minor or major
- Discuss the effect of the action on the child
- Discuss appropriate behaviour strategies
- Record the meeting

DISCIPLINE IN THE CASE OF CONTRAVENTIONS III – CONSEQUENCES
Proven Minor Contravention:
- First offence – verbal warning
- Second offence – disciplinary letter
- Third offence – written training program with monthly reviews; dismissal if no improvement

Proven Major Contravention:
(involving prohibited practices)
- Physical restraint (except last resort safety situations)
- Confining a child unlawfully
- Harsh or degrading treatment
- Depriving basic needs

Disciplinary Action:
- First offence: disciplinary letter
- Second offence: suspension or dismissal
- Third offence: dismissal

Severe Major Contraventions:
- corporal punishment
- forcing a child to eat or drink

Disciplinary Action:
- First offence: immediate suspension without pay or dismissal
- Second offence: dismissal

Experiencing positive relationships in the early years has a long-term impact on health, mental well-being, and academic success.

SANITARY PRACTICES POLICY
All CMS facilities and equipment must be maintained in safe and clean condition. Staff and children must practice proper hygiene.

Personal Health Practices:
Staff wash hands:
- when arriving
- after using washroom
- after assisting children in washroom
- before/after food prep

Children wash hands:
- after washroom use
- before handling food
- after handling animals
- after using tissue

Facilities & Equipment:
- Toys washed weekly
- Tables wiped before/after meals
- Floors vacuumed/swept per schedule
- Carpets vacuumed daily and professionally cleaned seasonally
- Cubbies cleaned weekly
- Kitchen appliances kept clean
- Disposable eating supplies used when required
- Washrooms cleaned weekly by cleaners; checked daily

NUTRITION & WELL-BEING OF CHILDREN
CMS provides nutritious meals according to Canada’s Food Guide. Meals are served in a positive atmosphere with staff modelling behaviour and communication. Allergy lists must be displayed. Health concerns must be documented and reported. Illness forms must be completed when a child is picked up sick.

Supporting positive interactions (s.46 (3) (b))
Encouraging communication and self-regulation (s.46 (3) (c))
Fostering exploration and inquiry (s.46 (3) (d))
Providing child-initiated and adult-supported experiences (s.46 (3) (e))

CMS classrooms operate on the principle of freedom within limits and Montessori philosophy. Children work at their own pace with chosen materials. Older children mentor younger children, fostering leadership and cooperation.

Our aims include:
- Happy, secure, stimulating environment
- Encouraging independence
- Fostering creativity
- Supporting language development
- Enhancing fine and gross motor skills
- Encouraging exploration and self-expression
- Providing age-appropriate activities
- Supporting emotional growth
- Encouraging peer interactions
- Maintaining consistent routines
- Modelling respect and inclusion

Plan for positive learning environments (s.46 (3) (f))
CMS promotes total development and independence. Classrooms are prepared with accessible, complete, purposeful materials. Staff observe children to introduce new challenges and guide inquiry-based learning.
Free play fosters creativity and exploration.

Incorporating indoor/outdoor play, active play, rest, and quiet time (s.46 (3) (g))
- Rest period max 2 hours
- Children may sleep, rest, or engage in quiet activities
- Outdoor play min 2 hours daily (weather permitting)
- Large motor activities included indoors/outdoors
- Weekly programs: yoga, music, gym, obstacle courses, Rainbow Fun

Fostering communication with parents (s.46 (3) (h))
CMS maintains open communication through policies, calendars, newsletters, weekly updates, reminders, and posted program themes.

Involving community partners (s.46 (3) (i))
CMS collaborates with specialists (CCAC, Adventure Place) when extra support is needed. Third-party recommendations may result in program plans. Community helper visits and charity events promote connection and belonging.

Supporting continuous professional learning (s.46 (3) (j))
CMS supports staff learning through meetings, workshops, Lunch & Learns, annual reviews, observations, and updates from CCEYA.

As per s.46 (3) (k), strategies in sections (a)–(j) are reviewed through daily observation, reflection, and alignment with “How Does Learning Happen?”. Staff sign off annually and whenever revisions occur. Monitoring procedures ensure compliance.

This policy will be reviewed by staff, students and volunteers before they begin their employment at CMS, and annually thereafter or at any time a revision occurs. A record of this review will be signed and dated and kept for 3 years.
